name: Primidone (Mysoline)
summary: Primidone is an anticonvulsant used to treat various seizure disorders and essential tremor. It works by decreasing abnormal electrical activity in the brain.
description: Primidone, marketed under the brand name Mysoline, is a barbiturate-derived anticonvulsant. It is structurally related to phenobarbital and is metabolized into phenobarbital and phenylethylmalonamide (PEMA), both of which contribute to its antiepileptic effects. Primidone is effective in controlling tonic-clonic (grand mal), complex partial (psychomotor), and focal seizures, as well as essential tremor. It is taken orally and has a slow onset of action but provides long-lasting seizure control.

off_label_uses: Seizure prophylaxis in specific neurological syndromes

sections.text: Primidone is metabolized to phenobarbital and PEMA, both of which have anticonvulsant properties. These metabolites enhance GABA-mediated chloride influx at the GABA-A receptor, leading to neuronal hyperpolarization, and may also inhibit voltage-gated sodium channels, reducing neuronal excitability.

adult.Epilepsy: Start at 100–125 mg at bedtime; increase gradually to 750–1500 mg/day in divided doses
adult.Essential tremor: Start at 50 mg at bedtime; titrate to 250 mg twice daily as tolerated

sections.pediatric: Start at 10–25 mg at bedtime; titrate gradually to effect
sections.geriatric: Start low, titrate slowly; monitor for sedation and cognitive effects

sections.text: Onset: Gradual over several days to weeks; Duration: 12–24 hours

other: May cause sedation and cognitive impairment—use caution with driving or machinery
Risk of dependence and withdrawal—taper gradually when discontinuing
Use with caution in patients with hepatic or renal impairment

sections.pregnancy: Category D; risk of teratogenicity—use only if clearly needed
sections.lactation: Excreted in breast milk—monitor infant for sedation
sections.geriatrics: Increased sensitivity to CNS effects—start low, go slow

sections.text: Gradually reduce dose over several weeks to prevent withdrawal seizures

items: Primidone’s therapeutic effects may take several weeks to fully develop
In essential tremor, may be used alone or in combination with propranolol
Requires regular monitoring to ensure safe and effective dosing
